title: Mod Parts for Glitch's Stargate Mk2

description.text:
I'm very impressed with Glitch's Stargate Mk2. It's been the most complicated thing I've made so far. Based on the parts I could get on Amazon here in the US (quickly, as I had a deadline), I had to come up with a couple of mods.

I couldn't get the specified LEDs for the chevrons on time, so I got Chanzon SMDs with dimensions of 5.7 x 3.0 mm. As these were tiny, and hard to solder, I designed this little mounting bracket LED holder. It has 2 functions, hold the LEDs for soldering, and it'll fit nicely into the wiring slot of the Stargate.

I recommend gluing the LEDs in place (watch your orientation / polarity). While they nicely snap into the slots, a hot soldering iron will soften the plastic, causing them to fall out. I've been using E6000 High Viscosity Adhesive, as it has a longerish set time, letting me fix screw-ups. I clamped them on a vice "upside down" and soldered left over bits of resistor leads cut to size between, and added "leads" to later solder the main wires.

I recommend placing the gate_4_b_x6 on top of the wiring slot part (gate_3_b_x6, gate_3_a_x1, gate_3_e_x1, gate_3_d_x1), and mark the holes with a Sharpie. This will let you glue the assembly in the correct place. I also blackened the back of those pieces with said Sharpie to reduce light leak.

Once you've soldered them, test them (don't forget to use a resistor, so you don't blow the LEDs), then glue them into those marked places. The design lets you snake some thin wires through from the "upstream" LEDs. I used 26g wire. You can get one strand above, one below, 2 in the center, 2 the top LED (tight fit), and 2 under the bottom LEDs (tight fit). See the photo. To accommodate the wires, all the right chevron LEDs went on the right side (both positive and negative wires), and all the left chevron LEDs went on the left (duh), but the top chevron had the 2 wires split with one down the left side and one down the right side. This is important, otherwise one of the bottom chevron LEDs will be super tight.

I found the Light Dependent Resistor that came with my Arduino kit was 5.2 x 4.3mm, which didn't fit into the LDR holder (ldr_x1), so I also modified ldr_x1 to so it would fit.

Having less joints may help with a smoother rail, so I've tried joining the parts together which should fit my new mk3 set at a diagonal. This is theoretical, as I haven't actually printed this one yet, but may as my symbol ring keeps getting stuck right now.

Maybe I used the wrong glue, or my track wasn't smooth enough, but the joints between the symbols didn't hold. They'll still spin, but the resulting crack between was fooling the LDR calibration. So I printed up some symbol_clips_x5 to help secure the symbol connections. That did the the trick.

I found after lubricating the ring a bit too much, some silicone lubricant got on the stepper motor axle, and since my gears didn't print the flat part too well, they lost traction and would just spin, without rotating the gear_symbol_x1. So I made a version with a set screw hole for an M3 screw. I also made one for gear_chevron_x1.

I'm also including Glitch's circuit diagram, which you can find on his website: http://www.glitch.org.uk/category/stargate/ Note: the diagram pins correspond to the original (commented out) Chevrons array. Though I think pin 9 is swapped with pin 11 based on the Arduino Sketch in the final uncommented version.

LEDs: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CUGACEA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Arduino Kit (CD came cracked, so had trouble figuring out what was what): https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B074DVCW4B/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Glue: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0044SB3M8/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Glue Tips: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0141MQQCI/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Edit: Feb 20, 2018 - I added a jig or template to hold the gate parts together so they line up properly when gluing.

description.text:
Simple DIY compass circle cutter for circles from 31 to 468mm diameter or more (with longer square 10x10x1mm aluminium tubes).
All parts were printed with PLA+ filament, but normal PLA will do just fine

EDIT:
Added new V2 needle holder and pencil holder for Ikea pencils (they are free and half of length of normal pencil)

02.18.2017
Added new holder for X-Blade Knife
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/x-blade-precision-knife-with-replaceable-sk-5-blade.html

Printer:

Geeetech i3 PRO B

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

45%

Notes:

Support is only needed on part "needle holder", but only where hex hole is. Just rotate original part by 180° and on bottom of part is "support" added. I used ESUN PLA+, head temperature 220°C, heatbead at 60°C and printing speed 60mm/s, retraction 10mm and cooling fan on.
Use 4 lines for walls and 5 layers for top/bottom, flow 102% for Esun PLA.

First remove support from part called needle holder and glue part holder_1 together with thin CA. Before gluing parts together check fitting, if to tight, some sanding will be needed. Then cut aluminium square 10x10x1mm tubes 220mm long (if needed cutter for greater diameters, cut them longer), make sure they are both same size. Sand inner edges with sandpaper or use files for metals.Then sand end_part to get it 10mm width and 26,2mm tall. Rest of it should go together without problems. Maybe some little sanding will be needed on blade holder, to get it inside hole. Also sand edges of hole and inner walls to get smother surface.
I also added small pads for centre needle in case you don't want hole in circle. Use 2mm moosgumme (2mm thick foam rubber), cut it to fit in pads and apply some contact glue to fix them in place.

I made short time lapse video of assemble
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wJUvXOchDAI
https://youtu.be/lH7_sIqgxTk

To finish compas cutter you will need:
1x M6x30mm NYLON(Plastic)HEX Hd BOLT screw + nut + washer
1x M4x20 hex head screw
10x10x1mm square aluminium anodised tube (you can also use normal tube)
2mm steel wire 20mm long for needle. Just sand one end to get sharp cone.

18mm snap off blades or vinyl cutter blades

Just look on ebay for vinly cutter blades that have 2mm body diameter, something like this: https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/5pcs-30-45-60-Degree-For-Roland-Cutting-Plotter-Vinyl-Cutter-Knife-Blade/332427539103?hash=item4d6639b29f:m:msF7ZmARud-rnqsgWQe5znw
You will also need 2x 3x8x4mm ball bearings, 15mm long 3/2,1mm and 15mm long 9/8,1mm brass round tube ( aluminium tubes can be also used, you can get them at local RC model shop), some CA or epoxi glue for gluing blade into tube.

Used to tighten m5 nuts into hard to reach spots.
This one is also available in m3 size
Print the part with wide flat part to the bottom.
Print with slow speed, because the printer starts to oscillate if you print too fast.
If the fit with the nut is too loose, decrease the XY dimensions.
If the fit is too tight, increase the XY dimensions

title: LGB - Aster Frank S tender gastank tub

description.text:
In 1989 LGB joined forced with Aster in Japan and released the Frank S live steam locomotive.

The gas-tank in the tender is mounted in a plastic tub. To avoid freezing of the tank the tub is filled with warm water. After years of service the original plastic tub became brittle and started leaking. It was beyond repair.

This is a direct replacement for the original tub.
It can be printed without supports in PLA.

19FEB18: The initial designed tub fits very tightly in the tender. It is a fully functional replacement. Unfortunately there is currently no space any more for the wiring of the RC-components. The battery and receiver are located in the tender. 3 servo's control the driving direction, regulator and whistle.
To allow for cables to be fitted between tender and locomotive I've redesigned the tub. It is narrower, has rounded corners and a recess has been created (diam 35 mm) to mount the tank securely. Version 2 has a perfect fit for the gas-tank and allows the cables to be fitted.

title: CR-10 Rotating Arm Adapter for Camera Mount

description.text:
I absolutely love RaffoSan's CR 10 BED camera mount and have been using it for a while now.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2491366

However, I desired a little more flexibility in its movement and specifically the ability to bring the camera down low over the print bed or sometimes to rotate the camera off to the side of a print to get closeups.

The features I was shooting for was good rotation but also being stable and allowing you to tighten the joint so it doesn't move while printing. This is not my first attempt at this but the first I'm willing to display publicly! This uses tapered threads to tighten on a 10mm post. And I've been using it now for several weeks and many hours of printing. It's working quite well, it doesn't slip or move once it's tightened and allows me to twist my camera mount in a lot more positions.

Special thanks as well to loco and his "Self-centering tapered-thread Z-axis coupling" which I used in part to make this.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602481

And also thank you to aubenc for their knurled surface library:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32122

I've also created a bi-directional adapter for the Microsoft Lifecam that I happen to be using here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2760919

All of the mounts that fit the original will work with this but they might be better if rotated 90 degrees for example. I've not had time to make any other camera mounts, so let me know if you have one that you need adjusted, I'll see what I can do.

Video timelapse sample showing stability:
https://youtu.be/r7RzW7fvfyc

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I'm specifying a high infill percentage here because I did have one test print snap the post off while twisting it in the tapered thread collet... this prompted me to adjust my slice setup so that I was printing just the layers where the post connects with 100% infill.

This is fairly easy to do in Simplify3D using the Variable Settings Wizard but if you're using another slicer, I would recommend printing at least the post piece at 25% or higher infill.

I had good success printing with the pieces in the orientation you see here. Just turn on normal supports to be safe and make sure you have good first layer adhesion.

author: Fangli

description.text:
One of the handles on my Bosch fridge/freezer side-by-side combination broke. New ones are hard to find and expensive, so I designed my own replacement version.

The original handle (right side on the picture) is swiveled, but I decided to do a similar looking but simplified fixed version instead (left one) because the material thickness would have otherwise been insufficient for adequate strength.

The three mounting screws of the original handle can be re-used, but only the one in the middle is directly visible, the two smaller screws are hidden underneath the original swiveled handle and are only revealed once the handle is removed. In some cases, it might be necessary to replace the two smaller screws with slightly longer ones in case they fail to reach the thread inside the fridge door when mounting the new handle.

Printed in PLA without support. Layer height 0.2mm, infill 75%.

description.text:
My son wanted this for his locker, so I whipped it up real fast in fusion 360.

I painted dark blue with white on the top edges.

Simple build if you are new to 3d printing.

I gave him some foam 2 sided tape for his locker.

He loved it!

First, MAJOR MAJOR credit goes to the original creator of this Y Belt Tensioner. One of the best tensioners I've used. Nice looking and doesn't take a lot of space. However, it doesn't have the ability to adjust the LEFT/RIGHT position of the belt to align with the plate, which I desparately needed in order to solve my belt scraping problem. So this is a quick and easy solution and you don't need to modify anything.

What's with the weird hearted shape? Well, it's got nothing to do with Feb 14 and it's not a heart =) It's just a shape that I used to help create a stronger structure for sliding and locking.

Nut and screw holes are deeper than original to allow you to use shorter screw/bolt, giving more room on the sides for sliding to adjust your belt position.

==========
Note:

Make sure you clean the sliding surfaces before use. that way you can install and adjust the slider position easily without having to use too much force. It is designed to be tight fit but not too tight. Loose connection between the 2 parts will result in stretching so DO NOT sand the surfaces too much. I only had to clean the seams and trim the edge of the first layer a bit.

I didn't include the Plate or the Screw STL files. If you want those files then please download them from the original creator and please give the guy a shoutout.

0.2mm Layer Height

20% Infill

description.text:
I have the Anet A2 Plus with the 270 bed. I didn't feel the need (right now) to use the whole bed for my printing needs. 220 glass is more readily available and so that is what I went with. I am using thermal pads on the corners to adhere the glass to the bed. The measurements for these clips account for centering 220x220 glass on a 220x270 heated bed:
(3mm hotbed) + (0.5mm thermal pad) + (3mm glass)

There are notches on the underside of the clips to avoid interference with the bed leveling springs.

I went through a few revision of this. Firstly trying with smaller size and coverage but those seemed to slip off too easily. For my application, I found that a larger clamp on the just the uncovered edges of the hotbed works really well to apply just enough pressure to hold the clamp securely in place.

author: squonk

title: Stand for Smartphone or Tablet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are already a lot of smartphone/tablet stands out there that [I] [really] [like]. (Here's [my favorite].) But I wanted to make my own, and I wanted the design to have all the features I felt were essential to a good iPad stand:

  • Stability: I want to be able to tap the surface with confidence.
  • Selectable view angle, including a very steep angle (~80°).
  • Foldable/collapsable so it can fit in a drawer.
  • Usable with every iDevice in my household: my wife's iPhone 5, my iPhone 6s, and our first generation iPad Airs.
  • The stand should excessively extend beyond the device.

This stand is what I came up with.

I laser cut my stand on a Glowforge. You may have to adjust the line width and color depending on your laser cutter and software. This design also requires 3/8" dowel stock which you will cut to size.

Cutting Dowels and Assembly

You will need to cut lengths of dowel stock to suit your preference. I chose to make my dowels a little longer than 10.5cm (4.13in) so that an iPhone 5 would fit sideways on the stand. Cut the support dowel for the slotted pieces a little shorter—twice the width of your plywood shorter. Similarly for the dowel on the swinging end of the support beam.

The assembly is pretty much self-explanatory. You just need to know to use the pressure fit holes on the support beam for the swinging end, not the hinge end.

Design Notes

I measured my 3/8" dowel stock with calipers and did a test cut of a pattern of hole sizes (attached) ranging from the largest measurement taken of the dowel down to, say, 1.5 mm smaller than the largest size, which turned out to be way overkill. I used Adobe Illustrator’s Blend Tool to do this easily. I ended up with a bespoke measuring device for 3/8" dowel stock that looks like this:

This gave me the exact sizes I needed for different kinds of fits. The stand uses at least three sizes of holes, one each for: hard pressure fit, loose fit for moving “hinges,” and very loose fit for the catch slots. Despite its appearance in some of the pictures, no glue is necessary for this design.

remixed_from.title: CR-10, CR-7, Ender - Dial Indicator Mount for Bed Level (Remix for larger fanducts)

title: Harbor Freight Dial Indicator Mounting kit for CR-10 (2017-2018 )

description.text:
I found a mount that would fit my [current year] CR-10, tested it, and it worked well. I soon realized that I would need hardware to pin it in place and planned on stopping by the hardware store but didn't due to having a busy Valentine's Day. I figured I could either spend an hour or so driving to the hardware store the next day, or I could print something out and have it ready when I woke up in the morning.

Ideally the "hardware" should be printed in something like nylon, but PLA @ 100% infill seems to work just fine.

Thanks goes out to the original designers. You can view their profiles to see further details on their original and remixed work. Be sure to visit https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412647 to obtain and learn how to use bed leveling gcode. You don't want to auto-home if the bed is too high with the dial in place, just in case your dial is too long and your bed could be impacted.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

60-100%

Notes:

Bed plate supports only, not everywhere.
60% infill on the mount, though it could probably withstand 40%
100% infill on the "hardware"
Be sure bolt is oriented upwards

The washer is set at 1.75 mm thickness, though 2 mm could possibly work as well for a slightly more flush look and feel.

Mounting

Slip the dial through the mounting slot, pin it in place with the bolt, orient the hex head into place, slip the washer over the other end, then finger tighten the nut into place.
Don't overdo cleaning up the hardware. In this case friction is desired.

I used the Nut Job files and entered parameters based off the measurements I pulled from my calipers. Max surface area was in mind for clamping the stiffness of PLA. The mount itself was unmodified, but is included in this file to make things easier.

This is my first attempt at a larger scale 3D Model. This is the Print N Play Arcade! Check out the video on it here, and watch my channel for the tutorial popping up over the next week.

https://youtu.be/DTO9fZlOYeE

I also want to thank my friends over at Matterhackers for sponsoring this build! The final version was printed in their Pro-PLA filament, and it turned out beautiful!

I've tried to label the parts as best I can. Standard parts are the upper body, screen bezel, lcd controller mount, and rear hatch. From there, you can select your controller layout, the type of rear panel you want, and either the bottom with mounts for the orange pi and speakers included in my BOM, or an empty one that you can install whatever you want in.

Print the base of the unit upright, no supports. Print the upper part of the unit with its back on the bed, with supports touching the bed only. I've tried to make sure that everything else prints without supports.

I can't wait to see what you guys make with this! Make sure to post pictures of any builds on here. And, as always, a shout out to my channel when you show them off is always appreciated :)

You should need less than 1KG of material for this build, but I hightly recommend using two different colors to get the best effect. This is still a bit of a work in progress, as I haven't come up with a method for hanging the marquee that I am satisfied with

title: Mount for Precision Piezo Univeral PCB v2

description.text:
Just a simple block to mount the universal pcb from Precision Piezo to DJDemonD's Piezo20 hotend mount. It has two countersunk holes for mounting the block to the Piezo20 dome part then two holes for the Universal PCB. One version has 3.9mm holes for m3 heatset inserts. The other has 2.5mm holes you can drill and tap for m3 or use small sheet metal screws.

DJDemonD's design works really well but doesn't have a way to mount the universal pcb. As a result, every time I tried to use it, the delicate piezo wires would break after no time. I assembled and reassembled like 10 times before I realized to could bang out a quick adaptor in Fusion360. I'm a little slow but I get there eventually. :D

title: Simchair MKIII cyclic gimbal with B8 flight stick replica

description.text:
This is a Simchair MKIII cyclic gimbal with a detachable stick. Easy to print and assemble, precise, with its sensitive parts protected with enclosure, designed to be mounted under the chair at an angle (to be protected from dust and not to protrude from under the chair when not being used) - this one provides far better flying experience than the MKII version. No hardware adjustments are required after building it - just fit everything into its place, calibrate it and fly!

You will need:

1 x 80x10x10mm aluminum square pipe
1 x 65x10x10mm aluminum square pipe
1 x 35x10x10mm aluminum square pipe

IKEA GUNDE CHAIR (optional): http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/00217797/
simchair IKEA GUNDE frame (optional): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2795691
2 x SS495A hall sensor

2 x 6x6x4mm square magnet
4 x 3x12mm screws and nyloc nuts to connect the frame to its enclosure
2 x 3x25mm screw for lever connector axis strengthening
4 x m8x75 bolts, spring washers, and nuts
4 x 608 bearings (standard skateboard bearings)
cyanoacrylate to assemble B8 stick and cyclic lever, also to glue SS495A's and their wires
to their mounting spots
1 x some nice joystick controller, the Simchair MKIII one will do (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2775102)

I have tested this thing in DCS and it feels great! However, note that as everybody's printer is a bit different, it will require software calibration, either in windows or in simchair controller firmware. This process is very easy though and should only be done once.

This package contains a modified version of a great B8 flight stick replica by schrodingers_cat, with dummy buttons included. No real buttons, for now, but I will add them later.
(original: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:776116)

description.text:
RingSpace, the earring display carousel that somewhat reminds of a spaceship. It can be as small as one story, yet, easily be extended to as many stories as your filament can carry.

Originally designed to not buy a similar item from everyone's favourite online store has it now become a project of it's own. Of course the misses has a long list of demands for future additions, re-designs and expansions to this impromptu valentines gift.

That way you can check back every once in a while or start following the RingSpace to see upcoming changes, updates and new modules.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10% Honeycomb, 4 Perimeters, 4 Top/Bottom Layers

Notes:

Printed in Eins3D Fun+ white PLA filament at 190º C. Bed temperature at 55º C and printed with 10 mm brim that may or may not have been necessary. Print without the brim in case you have really good adhesion to avoid post print processing.

M20? Screw that!

I decided to add 20 mm long M20x2.5 threads for all the parts to keep the modules together. Turns out this way the carousel cannot spin. It is however pretty sturdy even at 10% infill.

You can print and screw on as many of the rsRing pieces as you like. Every ring has holes for up to 15 earrings. The rsHat adds another 15 ring holes.

There will be new modules in the future - some of them are already in my head and just need to be poured into Fusion360.

Other practical things ...

So you like things with a purpose? Why not check out HatHat, the Simplest "floating" Hat Hanger? Or BloqChain, the Easy Zero Infill Chain Links.

description.text:
A helmet I designed on Blender to be used on Desktop Hero, greatly inspired by the warriors form the Myth saga by Bungie.

This is the first of many more models I'm planning on doing to create my own miniatures from the game, as a hobby and practice 3d modelling.

Newdominion's TOS Klingon Disruptor was terrific, but it had a single lozenge-shaped side-piece floating a few inches off to one side of the barrel. I mirrored that, and moved the two pieces so they could be merged with the the end of the barrel, giving a slightly more accurate appearance. I set the size to 2.5" length, which is a pretty accurate one-sixth of the length of the original prop. The result is good to be held by a 12" action figure.

Warning! There seems to be something weird about the handle of this model. It looks perfect in the software, but it wants to print in a weird, twisted form. That's beyond my skill to repair, but I hope someone here can do it.

title: Dehydrator Tray Extension for Westinghouse WFD100W

description.text:
Many comments on a dominant e-tailer's site suggested this was a good food dehydrator to use for drying filament, but most also pointed out that you had to cut apart the racks, preventing its intended use for drying food, and Westinghouse doesn't seem to sell spare racks.

These extensions fit between existing racks to separate the racks enough to fit a filament spool in-between. NOTE that this is ONLY for the model WFD100W ... there is a slightly more expensive "101" model which looks to have different trays.

The 73mm high extension -- along with the height of the rack you put it on -- allows the widest spool I have (just over 80mm) to fit with a filament clip still attached to the side. If you print just one set, this would probably be the most useful. This one is white in the photos.

I printed the 88mm extension set (yellow in the photos) before noting that I would get extra vertical space from the tray onto which I place the extensions.

The 28mm version was just to test fit; I never printed a full set. I think it would accommodate spools about 35mm thick, roughly 1-3/8" --- I've never seen any that skinny. I included it only because I had the file already, Maybe it would be useful if you print the 73mm version and find you really need just a bit more after all?

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support on BUILD PLATE ONLY. You do need to support the curved wall, but you do not want to clog up the pin holes. If you're printing the pin pegs separately (or your slicer supports it), they probably don't really need support.

Print six (6) of the extension pieces and at least six (6) of the pin pegs. I went with 8 pin pegs to have spares. On one run I lost one in the mess of my "office;" on the other, one came unstuck from the bed about halfway through. (Fortunately, I saw it and was able to remove it and the air-print string of its remaining layers before damage was done to the rest.)

Because PLA will soften at drying temperatures, you should probably stick with ABS/ASA; PETG should be okay, too. The square "feet" that hold the pin holes seem to be adequate to help prevent ABS warping without a brim, but I did print them in an enclosure (the white ones).

Assembly

Assemble the six pieces in a circle with one peg in-between each adjacent pair. (In the holes; push together firmly.) If you think the slight gaps between pieces will be problematic, I'd probably try that aluminum tape used for HVAC ducts.

Place at least one rack below and one rack above the extension ring. No need to modify the racks.

FreeCAD file

If you would like a size I didn't include, my apologies that the FreeCAD file is not very well organized. Expand the tree from MainArc-ExportWithPinHoleBlocks > Fusion002 > MainShape > Fusion > UpperArc-Controls Height > Cylinder

This Cylinder controls the total height... presently it's 78mm high and 10mm up which gives the 88mm total height of the largest version I needed. If you need is smaller, reduce the height; larger, increase it and also increase the height of the Cylinder001 next to it that cuts it out.

You will also want to adjust the z position of the upper_pin and upper_pin_support inside Fusion002 by the same amount you change the height of the cylinder.

Make sure select all three of the "MainArc-ExportWithPinHoleBlocks" along with the "PinHoleBlock" and "PinHoleBlock001" when exporting your STL.

Emmett's Parametric Pins

I'd just made a few of Emmett's heart gears for Valentine's Day (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243278), so it seemed natural to use those pegs to hold the segments together.

I also checked with Emmett who agreed it would be easier to just include the file I used, so recognizing that it's not my OpenSCAD program, that tweaked file is here too (pin2-10x5.scad). Thanks again, Emmet!

If you'd rather start with his original pin2.scad, the parameters I changed arelength=10;, diameter=5;, and hole_twist=1;.

To make my life a little easier in combining the elements in FreeCAD, I added a translate and rotate to the pin hole, inserting a translate and rotate into line 24 of his .scad as follows:
if(object==1)translate([0,0,,diameter/2])rotate([-90,0,0])pinhole(r=diameter/2,l=length,nub=snap,fixed=hole_twist,fins=fins);

You need to set object=0 to generate the pin peg, export that STL, and then set object=1 to generate the solid for the hole which then is subtracted as Boolean cut (for example) from some other object.

title: Dad's Funnel, Large and Small Size, Its a round funnel with a rectangular end.

description.text:
My dad needed a funnel with a rectangular end, the images show the dimensions, all in metric.

The large funnel is 125mm tall, the funnel end is 150mm in diameter, the rectangular end is 25mm x 50mm, and 25mm long, thickness for everything is 5mm, but when printed the
thickness seems to be about 2.5mm, must be a mistake on my end.

The smaller funnel is 125mm tall, the funnel end is 100mm in diameter, the rectangular end is 25mm x 50mm, and 25mm long, thickness for everything is 5mm, but when printed the thickness seems to be about 2.5mm, must be a mistake on my end.

I noticed when I 3D printed the funnels the wall thickness is around 2.5mm and not 5mm, not sure what happened, but the funnels work fine and print good for me, I guess I need more practice LOL

I included a push block, its 15mm thick, 40mm wide, and 100mm tall.

I made this with Punch! ViaCAD 2D/3D v10 and included its save file along with a STL and STP file.

When I made the smaller funnel I used different tools inside of Punch! ViaCAD to make the smaller funnel, and the funnel failed to export correctly to STL, exporting to STL changed how the funnel looked inside of Punch! ViaCAD to a distorted shape, however the STL file looked good in Cura but when printed it always was a solid shape and not a funnel, I found that you could export to STP in Punch! ViaCAD, then import the STP file back into Punch! ViaCAD, then export to STL, and then file looked correct and 3D printed correctly.

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.3

I used 100% for the large funnel, 30% for the small funnel.

Notes:

Both funnels 3D printed well using low quality settings, no supports, I used PLA, but might be better using PETG or something with more flexibility, the large funnel took all night to print with a 0.4 nozzle I think 7 to 8 hours, I printed the smaller funnel and push block with 30% infill and that seemed to work well, the print time for the smaller funnel seemed to be about 4 hours from what I could remember.

author: will1384

description.text:
This is powerful tool meant for daily office use :)
It can be used in many situations to help you with conflict solving, punishment, or just pure revenge.

How it works:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/tisqgm1mumcrdu0/firing_90_480p.mp4?dl=0

The handle of the lower part easily warps, so I recommend to use a heated print bed.
Mount the upper part with the lower part as the black gun shows in the picture.
Mount the sides of the handle and the spring from the clothespin as shown.
If needed, fill the handle with something heavy (eg. led from your fishing gear).
Pull the sled fully backward and forward, insert the match and pull the trigger.

There is an optional challenge here. The gun can be equipped with a spring from a ballpoint pen to make the sled automatically enter its resting position. In this case the flexible tounge above the barrel of the lower part should be broken off. The spring should then be mounted in the small void between the rear end of the lower part and the 5 mm inset on the upper part. This step i quite challenging..

Note. This thing is not harmless, so dont shoot at anything alive.
I also provide the sketchup file in case someone needs to make adjustments or a remix.
Enjoy!

title: Vivitar TX rear lens cap (short version)

description.text:
Rear lens cap for Vivitar / Soligor interchangeable-mount lenses, for use when a mount is not fitted. This is the short version for telephoto lenses that do not have a protruding rear element. It works with Vivitar TX and T4 lenses, and Soligor T4 lenses.

This is version 2, modified into a two-piece design. The original one-piece version tended to wobble on a surface if the base of the lens cap wasn't perfectly flat. Now the smaller piece fits inside and needs to be glued in. The hole in the larger piece then forms a central recess in the base, so it sits more steadily on a surface.

Trim off lug supports

Underneath each lug, there is a series of tiny chamfered webs that act as temporary supports during printing. They need to be trimmed off with a sharp knife, and the lug itself needs to be trimmed to the required thickness. When it is fitted, the lens locking ring should be able to rotate easily without binding on the lugs.

Lug support webs

description.text:

This is version 2, modified into a two-piece design. The original one-piece version tended to wobble on a surface if the base of the lens cap wasn't perfectly flat. Now the smaller piece fits inside and needs to be glued in. The hole in the larger piece then forms a central recess in the base, so it sits more steadily on a surface.

Trim off lug supports

Underneath each lug, there is a series of tiny chamfered webs that act as temporary supports during printing. They need to be trimmed off with a sharp knife, and the lug itself needs to be trimmed or filed to the required thickness. When it is fitted, the lens locking ring should be able to rotate easily without binding on the lugs.

My wife takes care of kids and she bought an Exer Saucer from someone cheap because they had misplaced one of the pieces that attached to it. She figured I could make her a replacement. So, I took out one of the other ones, went to TinkerCad, (thank you TinkerCad!), and designed a piece to fit into it. She wanted a ring on it so she could attach a set of toys to it for the babies to play with.

I printed it on a CTC Dual Bizer using M3D ABS-R. I printed without raft, but with supports. (Yes, that did make for a bit of cleanup, but it wasn't bad.). I also printed it at 90% infill, (I figured babies aren't too strong, but I wanted it to stand up to time and time again of pulling on it.)

You will have to shave off a bit of the corners on the two retaining pieces on the side that push in to insert, (I forgot to make them rounded), but that is not a problem either.

If anyone needs to replace one on their Exer Saucer, I hope this work for you. (You could possibly use it to make anything on the top by editing it in a CAD program.)

here's a link to buy one, they're $24.55 currently (!): https://www.repairclinic.com/PartDetail/Knob/07509600/1770004

I bought my snowblower and it was missing the knob to rotate the chute. The shaft is 3/8" diameter. I bought a 3/8" push nut at the local hardware store for 30¢, and printed the rest. filament cost: $1.05. I saved $23 printing this vs. buying it. The code (sans variable definitions) is roughly 40 lines. That's over 50¢ saved per line of code!

The gear shifter knob on mine appears to use a larger shaft, so double check the shaft size before you print. You can easily tweak the scad file to adjust the size.

I printed the parts as oriented, with support for the knob. I would recommend having your support alternate directions, part of my support fell over while printing (print still succeeded though, can't even tell there was a problem).

title: New York Slice Board Game Insert
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Insert for the board game New York Slice. Keeps the slices in a more thematic pizza shape in the box, rather than a big mess or other stacking methods. There are holders for the cards as well.

Corner is available in two styles: Plain and with the New York Slice logo.
The logo doesn't take much time and looks nice, but may be overkill to have on every corner.

Print four of the corners of whichever style you want, plus four of the spacers. If you have a larger print bed, print four of the joined parts instead. Holes are in the back of the corners to save filament since it does not act as a container, only the surface facing the inside is structural

Print two specials card holders.

Corners go in the corners, spacers in between. They should all fit with only a little wiggle room to spare. Card holders loosely clip onto the corner pieces so they don't slide too much in the box.

If you have trouble getting the slices out, remove a piece of the insert and then put it back after. I was going to attempt to put a divot in one of the pieces to make it easier, but removing a piece is just as easy.

The card holders ended up a little higher than intended. They raise the lid a tad, but toward the front it's not a large factor.

title: Park Tool lockring tool converter from 5mm QR to 12mm thru axle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've got the Park Tool FR-5.2G cassette lockring tool for removing and installing cassette lockrings. The 5mm guide pin is nice to keep it aligned when using it on a quick-release style hub, but what about the newer 12mm thru-axle hubs? You could buy the Park Tool FR 5.2GT which has the 12mm guide pin, but then you've got two separate cassette lockring tools.

Instead, you could print out this handy little converter, and be able to use one FR-5.2G for both types of hub. It's designed to fit nicely inside a 12mm thru-axle and fit over the 5mm guide pin of the lockring tool with a tighter fit at the end of the tool to keep it from accidentally slipping off. It should still fit loose enough that you can easily remove it by hand. Depending on the accuracy of your printer, it may require a little bit of sanding afterwards, but it should be good right off the bat.

It could be longer, but I don't feel that's necessary - the current length is plenty to guide the tool without any slop. If you really want it longer, the 5mm guide pin is 55mm long, and I made the part 40mm long. Scale it in the Z axis by 37.5% in your slicer and you should wind up right around the same length as the guide pin, but I don't think it's really going to buy you anything. Also, since the end of the nose is designed to be a light interference fit to hold it in place, you don't have to push it all the way into the tool and you'll get a little bit more engagement that way.

Works with Shimano or SRAM lockrings, 11 or 12t, as well as SRAM 1x cassettes.

title: Tweezer holder for Prusa MK2 and MK3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use a pair of tweezers (or is it one tweeze?) a lot when printing and I like to have them handy. This holder clips to the vertical frame of the Prusa MK2 and MK3. Note that the MK3 frame is 5mm narrower than the MK2 frame, so choose the correct model for your printer.

The holder doesn't interfere with Z-axis movement when used on the right side of the frame. If you put it on the left side it will impact on the X-axis motor, so don't do that.

Note that I have, once again, taken Area51's clip design (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1940105) and used it in my own design. I have reverse-engineered it into OpenSCAD to make it easier to fit projects of mine that mount on the Prusa's frame.

description.text:
This is the Planet Express in the year 3030, as shown in Season 6, Episode 7 of Futurama.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Late_Philip_J._Fry

This model took me a lot of time, and I could still add some additional details at some point. I'm calling it finished as of now though, because I'm sick of working on it. Includes STL's for individual parts of the building, for easier printing. I also included an STL of the complete building. I'm not bothered to provide instructions for assembly, so use the complete STL as reference.

Anet A2Plus Modular X Carriage
Designed with reference to the Modular X carriage for Tevo Tarantula.
Compared with tevo, the width of A2 is narrow so that the movable range of X axis can be used widely.
Adjusted to dimensions for eccentric nut.

Please use the belt lock for "Tevo Tarantula Modular X Car Basic, e3d 2x".

Eccentric nuts (2 pieces) and spacers (adjusted according to eccentric nuts with their own height: 2 pieces) are necessary.
Attachment for "original hot end" and "Titan - E 3 d v 6 (clone) for direct connection" was included.
M4 * 12 to 15 3 sets are required for connecting the module base and attachment.

Previously, the mechanical section was designed with the left and the motor coming to the right, but the nozzle was inconvenient because it got separated from the X carriage rail. (The red parts of the photo are arranged)
In this time we arranged the motor to the left and made the nozzle closer to the rail.
In my environment "motor left" is convenient, "motor is right" is also made.
If there are 2 or 3 requests, I plan to release it in addition.

title: AWB Onesky Rack and Pinion Focuser

description.text:
I found the rotary focuser that came with my AWB Onesky a bit hard to use with a camera, so I purchased an Orion 13031 and made the new pieces to fit it.

You will need a few M3, M4, M5, and M6 rivet nut inserts, I used these https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LWKGGGM

2ea M3x10 if you want to mount a shroud, I will be using Kydex and will drill holes to attach it directly.
4ea M4x20 to mount the focuser.
2ea M6x10 to mount the focuser assembly to the endcap assembly.

Downside is that the new focuser is 1 1/4" taller than the stock focuser. This means that you will need to lower the end assembly the same amount to be able to focus on anything. I may design my own focuser in the future, but have not made a decision on that yet.
Lowering the end assembly may not be required when mounting a camera, depending on how many extensions you had to add on the original focuser.

title: Monoprice Select Mini V2 3mm Glass Bed Z-Spacer

description.text:
This is a z-axis spacer for the Monoprice Select Mini V2 printer when installing a 3mm thick glass print bed. This does NOT require any disassembly of the printer to install. To install, manually move your printer nozzle UP on the z-axis about 3/4". Snap this model (thicker side down) around the black box that you can see through the small gap.

Now home your printer axis, this should lift the z-home 3mm higher. I've additionally added an STL file for those needing 3.5mm of offset.

I personally use this one https://www.amazon.com/dp/B075XJ5ZP1/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_esLHAbESGRX0P

It's the "130mm x 160mm Borosilicate Glass Plate Bed Flat Polished Edge w/ Corners Cut for 3D Print" by "GO-3D PRINT"

comments.text: Do you also use a thermal pad between your glass and the bed? I have this same glass and want to install this spacer but the thermal pad will add about 0.5mm itself.
comments.author: Helixer

comments.text: I do not. The aluminum bed has a heating element underneath it and the glass is clamped directly to the aluminum. If you want I can add another STL file that is .5mm thicker on the bottom; that should cover your use case.
comments.author: Helixer

comments.text: Sure that would be great. Have you had any issues getting the glass to heat evenly? Maybe I will forgo the thermal pad also. Did you remove the black buildtak? I was thinking I would try leaving mine.
comments.author: MMDeveloper

comments.text: When I first got the printer I accidentally ripped up the black buildtak trying to remove a model stuck to it and I'd been using a wide roll of painters tape to print on. I don't have anything between the glass and aluminum. As far as heat transfer, I always print with the bed at 60 degrees and the top of the glass is probably around 57/58 degrees so the heat transfer is pretty good. It does take a little longer to heat up since the glass is absorbing some of the heat.
comments.author: Helixer

comments.text: Thank you for the updated file

Various sliding 2020 mounts.

  • RAMPS/2560
    • Print as per radds description
    • The bolt hole that isnt a hole but rather a spike may be too large. I forget if I fixed the stl or just cut it off mine.
  • RADDS/Due
    • Printing horizontally (as the stl is supplied) with supports inside the 2020 part is probably better than printing upright without supports.
  • 60xx fan
    • Print vertically without supports will work, but supports on the 2020 section protrusions will help.
    • Consider printing the grille twice, to protect the fan from the boards connector wires. Optional.

All mounts should lightly grip the 2020 with only friction. M4x10 bolts and t-nuts are used to lock the mount in position. Wingnut or other finger-adjustable nut heads recommended.

Printed:
PLA, 200C, 60C bed, 0.4mm nozzle, 0.3mm layers, 2.0mm walls/top/bottom, 20% infill but almost none is generated with 2mm walls. I prefer these mounts to be solid.

description.text:
This is an arm model I made mostly from picture analysis, but based somewhat on Starbuck Cylon parts and Gordon Tarpley's YouTube vids. The forearm is all one piece and the bicep is two. This was done to get a flat surface from which to start. The two pieces key together for alignment. This is intended for a large format printer like the CR-10 and I'm posting another version that might be more appropriate on smaller printers. I used 35% infill but it honestly probably doesn't matter too much where that's set. Most of the shaft is solid.

The forearm and bicep cuff are the same on both arms. The bicep body is handed so you'll want to reflect it when you print the left. The bar across the bottom of the bicep body is how the cuff is located rotationally so once you glue the parts together you can just trim that and sand it flush to the inside of the cuff. It also provides a little more surface area to adhere the part to the bed.

2/16/18 - update
I changed the holes at the elbow to be dimples instead. I noticed that during printing, the retraction when it went from one side of the hole to the other side made the inside of the elbow kind of weak. The dimple allows a continuous bead for the whole layer and it provides a positive locating feature to drill a clean hole. I also added a small nub on the outside of the elbow to locate the piston anchor. I'll be uploading the other greeblies and bits to complete the assembly.

title: Anet A8 Clip On Modular X Carriage - E3D v6 Bowden
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Work In Progress - Prototype

I wouldn't recommend printing this quite yet, but I thought I'd go ahead and post my WIP to see if there's any interest. Personally, I'm annoyed by all of the screws I have to screw and unscrew every time I want to tweak my x carriage, try some new bearings, remove my hotend to clean it, try a different z axis sensor. Or doing 10 hour prints multiple times because everything is all one piece...

So, I had the idea the other night to make everything clip on / hinge / removeable / swappable. So that's what I'm currently working on. After I get designs of parts done, I'll go through a testing phase and see what works and what doesn't. In the mean time, anyone else think this is a good idea?

Update 2/26/2018

My testing has been temporarily put on hold. The X-Carriage I was using was messing with my X-Axis, so I switched to a different carriage and when removing the cheap bearings that came with the A8, the balls started falling out all over. Replaced them with Igus Polymer bearings and they're sticking like crazy, causing layer shift. So I have new bearings on order that probably won't arrive until next week.

Update 2/19/2018

Almost done with my initial designs before I start testing. The remaining incomplete part is to hold the cooling fan. Still debating on whether I am going to do an attachment for the actual cooling or just try to allow integration of existing ones.

description.text:
I wanted a print of the deckbox that didn't have as much "Play" in the hinges, so I made one with a hinge similar to a door hinge, print the two bases, and the hinge bolt, then insert the hinge.

Be aware, the bolt for the hinge does require some pressure to get into place, which is why I recommend printing the bolt with 100% infill, or make the "First Layer" 700 layers tall, this makes the bolt entirely solid, it breaks otherwise.

The entire print can be done without supports, just print the boxes on their backs, and the bolt on it's base.

I widened the holes on one side of the deckbox so I could insert rare earth magnets, you can use the regular magnets, you'll just have to lift them a bit.

title: A 24 sided Die with 6 Sides? Tesseract inspired Die with 24 possible outcomes.

description.text:
This is a 6 sided Die with Tesseract (aka Hypercube) like features. A real Tesseract has 24 faces: 6 outer, 6 inner, 12 inside as typically configured. I left the outer and inner faces open and used the two sides of each of the 12 inside faces to hold a number to get a cube with 4 inner faces on each of the 6 sides (4*6=24 faces). I use an inner spindle object that will randomly fall towards one of the numbers with each toss. So this is a 6 sided Die with 24 possible outcomes.

Fun Fact: You may know that the sum of any two opposite faces on a normal 6 sided Die is 7. The Sum of all numbers on any two opposite faces on this 24 outcome Die is 100.

Does the 24 sided Tesseract have an opposite for each face?

There is another pattern that gets you a sum of 100 starting with any number - can you figure it out? Hint: Pick any number and travel around the equator (middle section), summing as you go.

This thing might even help you understand the 4th dimension - I'm still working on 1, 2 and 3D.

For kicks here is an animated model of a Tesseract posted by Hahnsolo420:

The STL has sliced and printed with great success on both Cura and Simplify3D. I've successfully scaled and printed this thing down to a 50% scale - which is just under 1" cubed. The full sized object is 50mm cubed (just under 2" cubed) and it is pretty sturdy.

Printing:
I suggest rafts and supports - especially since the inner spindle has only a small portion touching the bed on the first layer. Use the "Normal" or "supports everywhere" setting (as opposed to the "From build plate only setting").

Infill: 20% (or solid if you want more weight).
Layers: I suggest 0.1 or 0.2

description.text: This is a quick attach mount for a dial indicator to assist in bed leveling.

3) Snap mount around extruder and X carriage
4) Screw dial indicator into hole in mount.
5) Lower Z and play with your leveling screws until the dial doesn't move when X and Y change.

description.text:
I designed this tooth brush holder to keep debris off my tooth brushes and to prevent my cat from playing with them. Nothing is worse than knowing if your brushing your teeth with a mixture of toothpaste and cat residue. Will also accept 2-3 standard razors as well.

There are holes on the base of the body which allow airflow and water to freely drip off the tooth brushes and not sit in the holder for a clean area. I would highly recommend spraying this with a spray paint or other sealant to seal it as I have heard PLA allows bacteria to grow easily.

No supports are needed for this print. There are two small supports on the hinge pins for the lid that with either pop off or require snipping.

Print at .15 or better layer height.

There are two indents for accepting 3M command poster size strips or 2 holes for #8-10 screws. Of course you could also use suction cups if the holes work or regular double sided tape. The recess helps the tape hug the wall better.

title: Lilypad Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Lilypad a game by Jonathan A. Leistiko
A checkers variant for two players.
Every spring on May Day, sprites and spriggans, dryads and trolls across the world all gather together in a secret place for the Unseen Revel--one boisterous week of music, merriment, revelry and sport. One of the most popular games at the Unseen Revel is a simple game called 'Lilypad': Two tiny fairies try to race across a pond filled with frogs and turtles without getting wet, and the first one across wins. To complicate things, one fairy is allowed to only step on turtles and the other is allowed to only step on frogs, and they start on opposite sides of the pond.

(Oh, by the way... If little sprites dancing on turtles and frogs is too fey for you, then just pretend that you're futuristic gladiators battling on hover drones over a pit of red-hot magma. That should get your testosterone pumping.)

The players attempt to move their pawns across the board without being captured. The first person to get his pawn across the board wins. If both players' pawns are captured, the game ends in a draw.

I really liked lukaszsw's idea of holding the Gloomhaven monster sheets along with their decks and standees, but I wanted to easily differentiate between similar-sized boxes without getting my sloppy handwriting all over them, so I'm making my printer write for me.

I also ran the original through Sketchup's cleanup tool and rotated the front cover to reduce travel time on the upper layers.

The front and rear faces on these are a little thin, so be careful taking them off the hotbed. Can confirm that one entire case will fit on a 220x220 bed, and if you put them side by side, probably two.

Edit 2/27/2018: Slowly making tweaks to these cases :
1) trying for universal 1-, 6- and 10-sectioned lids
2) modifying the lid to actually stay closed without being impossible to open, probably looking at a small latch thing for that
2) Individual bases for each monster deck

I'd like to have the entire set stable, labelled and uploaded up here by the end of the month.

This prints at 0.0875 or 0.175 layer heights. Generally the only part that you should print at 80% infill is the M8x15mm bolt. Others can be printed at 20% - or if you rally want them stiffer, use 1.2mm for wall width.

Monoprice Select Mini

No

Notes:

Print the bolt at 80% infill - they have to be very stiff - everything else at 20%.

I used eSun PLA+ and ABS and they both work.

title: Marmo Over-Engineered 3d Printer Control Box - Tevo

description.text:
What I have designed here is an over-engineered control box that will hold an S-300-12 PSU, RaspberryPi (via separately printed bumper and then glued in place), 1 hot bed Mosfet, the MKS 1.4 board, a LM2596 Buck Converter and, the top cover of the MKS board that holds the fan. Yes, I know... ANOTHER control board case... This is my FIRST ever designed part and I hope it works for you.

This case will hold the PSU tight from the top and bottom and is designed to vent to the side through the spiral cutout. Cooling is passive but the PSU fan draws enough air in from the front that heat should not be an issue. If it is, the holes in the front are designed to fit a 40mm fan using bolts and nuts.

Parts should be printed FLAT with no support. Parts that need support have them built in as tear-away tabs that are easy to snap off and will break clean.

The top forward panel has two holes to place emergency stop button and keys. It is printed thick to support the possible pressing of buttons and switches with minimal bowing or flex. Blank top with no holes coming...

The holder for the MKS board has a ladder for wire strain relief. Use wire ties to attach the wires to the ladder so the wiring does not pull on the connectors. The USB connector CANNOT be used in this case as it is too close the side wall however, you CAN solder a USB pigtail directly to the underside of the MKS board (see picture of the underside of board).

Rear Panel is designed to take the fused and switched iec320 c14 plug. Three Aviation Connector (GX16-10) style 10 pin plugs are designed to handle ALL connections EXCEPT Hot End and bed, those go to the XT60 connectors. The XT60 connectors are deigned to fit TIGHT so solder them BEFORE you insert them into the part. They are also going to sit into a separate XT60 connector holder block. This means you install the connectors into the block and then you slide the block into the opening in the rear panel from the inside out. You can then glue the block in place or let the friction hold it. I designed it so that you can grip the block the while you are inserting or releasing the XT connectors instead of pulling on the connectors themselves. Basically, it acts like a small handle. You need to use the C14 Standoff in order to allow for clearance with the wiring and the top of the MKS board fan shroud.

Screw holes are meant for M2 self tapping (not metal threads) everywhere EXCEPT bottom front where M2.5 threaded are meant to be added. Bottom parts have a 1mm gap between the seams to allow for glue expansion. The front LCD panel holder is keyed to the front vent panel and slotted to fit tight.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10 - 20%

Notes:

Designed to print and fit on 200x200 bed. Parts should be printed FLAT with no support. Parts that need support have them built in as tear-away tabs that are easy to snap off and will break away clean.

description.text:
Assassins Creed Original thumb ring modeled in Maya and ZBrush. I printed the ring with Rhodium Plated metal on Shapways.

To avoid copyright issue, I can't add the ring to my Shapways store, but please take a look at my other rings collection: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/double-alfa

If this is your very first order on Shapeways, use this code upon checkout to get a discount up to %15: yb5m5

You don't have to buy from my collection, and you can upload your own model for printing as well to get the discount.

Adjusting Ring Size

I design most thumb rings with a default US 8 ring size, so when scaled up there will not be any issues with wall thickness as required for metal 3D printing.

To resize the ring to fit your finger size, please do the following:

  1. I recommend downloading and using Meshmixer, a free software from Autodesk.
  2. Download the ring.
  3. Import the ring to Meshmixer, and from the left menu choose Analysis/Measure.
  4. You should measure the inner diameter of the ring by choosing from the sub-menu Type: from edge to edge, Direction: outward (n), Snapping mode: Snap to Vertices.
  5. Click on the inner diameter of the ring and you'll get a red line and a reading on the right side.
  6. To scale up, go to the Edit menu/Transform, and increase any of the size values, making sure that Uniform Scaling is checked. Repeat the measuring process above until you get your correct finger size.
  7. Once done, make sure to export the model as STL Binary Format, recommended.
  8. Upload the ring to Shapeways and continue with the process of selecting approved materials.

title: Cup Holder Tree
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What is it?

It is a cup holder tree, which can hold up to 7 cups (4 on bottom, 3 on top).

Core ideas behind it?

Like with cities, living room is valuable and that leads to building things upwards to have more usage for each living area. As I wanted to have my cups easy to reach (not hidden in some shelf) and yet still be compact in space usage, I thought of a tree-like structure:

  • Possibility to store multiple cups on a visible stand.

  • Usage of upward building direction to safe space.

  • Use building volume of common 3D Printers

  • Allow storage of XXL cups

  • Like always: Only 3D printed material, lightweight, avoid support structures where possible and make it therefore cheap

Why this and not others?

Actually I found nothing comparable here on Thingiverse. Wanted to use a design and simply print it to save time, instead of developing my own solution, but thing didn't come even close for remixing or so. Originally I wanted to buy that hanger tree from Ikea, but it was so simple, expensive and ugly that I decided to check out 3D print possibilities. It is still maybe not the most pretty thing, but way more beautiful than the Ikea thing. ;)

What is the outcome?

Several iterations, as the concept of connecting multiple 3D parts for stability and low clearance was more challenging than expected. The construction itself wasn't too demanding regarding forces and loads, so avoiding screws and other components felt appropriate:

  • Following data based on ABS and 15% infill

  • Total printing time of ~22.5 hrs in average quality and speed (each part around 2.5 hrs).

  • Material usage: ~320g (cost around 7€ based on standard ABS material)

  • Quite tall stem, which may have warping if not sticking properly to printing bed. Printing with raft is recommended.

  • (Rock) solid stand, where I do not worry if it can hold the cups properly, when using ~15% infill

  • Almost no support material required, when printing in following directions:
    Leg (upwards) - no support required
     Base (upwards) - little support for the sliding area
    Stem (upwards) - little support around the hexagonal connector
     Leaf (downwards) - little flat support on holding area

  • Clearance and tolerances should work out for most printers: used 0.25 mm clearance between parts, which grants part sliding with a bit pressure

remixed_from.author: Pointedstick
remixed_from.title: RepRap X-carriage for self-aligning bronze bushings

description.text:
X-carriage for RepRap that uses two self aligning bushings on one shaft and a 180 degree bushing on the other shaft.  This eliminates the need for the shafts to be perfectly parallel and the spacing to be perfect.
See original part for more information on clamps and bushings.
For the 180 degree bushing, use 1/8" delrin dowels such as these: mcmaster.com/#97155A426

1) Print
2) Clean out bushing holes with a knife before inserting bushings.
3) Clean out dowel holes with a 1/8" drill
4) Insert dowels into holes.
5) Insert bushings. If they are too tight, clean the holes more. Don't force them or you may break the holders. They should fit snuggly.
6) Check fit of bushings on 8mm rod. If 180 degree bushing is too tight, you can scrape the edge of the dowels with a knife. Don't overdo it.
7) Align the bushings by inserting a rod through each one and aligning it to the other one. Then the rod should easily slide through both bushings.

description.text: OK, here's what I think is the final version of my plan to relocate the extruder on my CR-10 to feed filament up from below. I combined an extruder body, a relocating bracket, and a drag chain mount. I made the bracket and extruder body much thicker for strength and warp resistance so longer screws than stock will be needed. This version also has a better filament funnel on the sensor housing and a stiffener along the top of the bracket/extruder. I have not printed this to test yet but my V3 works fine so it should be alright. I hope. I'm not certain on the location of the drag chain mount, I may have to remix stevenfayer's base mount to move it into alignment, it seems his top mount is meant to sit further in than what I have but it's hard to tell.

print_settings.Notes:: Requires a precise slicing app and a well set up accurate machine due to the clearances applied between the puzzle pieces that slide together / fir on (lids).

title: Jigsaw Puzzle Containers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Jigsaw Puzzle Containers is a set of small, fun but practical containers for small things that look like a jigsaw puzzle and can be assembled in an endless array of configurations. Just work out which parts you need to achieve the desired fun storage look... and you can always add to it in the future.

Each piece is a simple print that have 50mm x 50mm x 30mm (H) external dimensions for the square storage section. Scaling up uniformly will be okay however scaling down will cause them to become increasingly hard to slide together / apart due to the clearances applied between mating pieces.

If your pieces won't slide into each other or lids don't fit try scaling the parts up uniformly by the same percentage. The images show well printed examples that fit together snugly. This requires precisely sliced file printed on accurate / well set up machines.

The lids are optional but recommended for a tidier finish. They look great printed in any colour, including with different coloured bases and lids. Have fun with making them colourful!

The pieces provided are as follows:

Corner - Just one layout with a mail and female joiner

Edge - Just one layout with one male and two female joiners

Centre - The common version to use is the 'Corner - 4' files which link into the inward facing edge female joiners. However three additional centre pieces are provided with 1 / 2 / 3 male joiners to make puzzles more configurable or simply more interesting shapes where just a single piece or a small number of pieces are preferred.

Jigsaw Puzzle Containers make great little gifts and additional pieces can be gifted over time. A fun, novel and unique configurable storage solution!

Please refer to the print settings and instructions for additional information.... and post images of your Jigsaw Puzzle Containers in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Supports:

No

STandrad / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% infill recommended

Notes:

Easy prints... just makes sure you have good build plate adhesion so the edges stay nice and square. This helps the puzzle pieces slide together easily.

Requires a precise slicing app and a well set up accurate machine due to the clearances applied between the puzzle pieces that slide together / fir on (lids).

Just complete your Jigsaw Puzzle, add contents to the containers and put the lids on!

Sliding the pieces together / apart is easier if you apply a light lubricant to the mating surfaces. This is a one-off treatment as dry PLA does not slide well against more dry PLA.

Barbed hose reducers. Great for that fish tank or hydroponic hobby. Every combination of the sizes listed below are available with 153 sizes in total.

These are reducers only - there are no equal joints. These will come in another upload soon. Please comment if you have any suggestions for variations on this product. And let me know if you find a use for these.

You may have to play around with your print settings to make these watertight. With my Flashforge Finder, I find a high resolution and 50% infill does the job. A 100% infill caused a build up of material, creating lumps on the surface.

The dimension below is the outside diameter (OD) of the fitting (not including the barbs). For a good seal the inside diameter of your tubing wants to be just less than the OD listed. The wall thickness increases with OD to give greater strength.

title: Connector - 90 degree bend, attachment between PET drinks bottle and hose

description.text:
Adapter for connecting a PET bottle to a hose. Push the ribbed insert into the end of the hose. Push the plug into the end of the bottle, in the direction required. The plug is tapered so that if the hose is pulled, it will be clamped tighter. The 90 degree bend can be screwed onto the end of the bottle to prevent the hose bending and blocking the water flow.

This was originally used to improve the flow rate in a makeshift drip irrigation system for a polyhouse.

Not suitable for long term use in drinking water supplies.

title: Leapfrog Creatr Z-hardstop with Raspberry Pi camera mount

description.text:
2014.04.29
Here's the first version of all parts for the complete installation. The Z-hardstop is installed by removing the bolts from the back of the bed. This should be installed flat against the bed and then refastened using the same bolts. Or, 40 mm bolts can be purchased to allow rubber grommets to be used to hold down the Z-hardstop. (Show in the photos.) Big thanks to zabana for fixing the Z-hardstop design.

Print the following
  • Camera Mount Z-saver
  • Camera Back
  • Camera Front Mount Right
  • Camera Link 10mm (2X)
  • Camera Link 20mm (2X)
    • Its best to print these with a skirt as the parts are small and odd shaped. The Camera Mount Z-saver can be printed either standing or laying down (See the photo.) Buy two (2) 10mm x 3mm bolts with locking nuts. Attach the camera links and camera mount using the bolts. Finally, run a 50mm ribbon cables from the camera to the Raspberry Pi.

description.text:
These are Hypercube 300 frame assembly tools. You can use the alignment too to hold extrusions square while putting the frame together/installing corner brackets.

Then use it as a gauge to space your middle Y extrusion exactly 120mm from the top Y extrusion and hold it there while you install the corner brackets.

Then use it to set your lower X and Y extrusions exactly 100mm from the table top.

The tool will hold extrusions in alignment using friction as printed however there are holes in the tool for inserting M5x10 screws and T nuts if you want to hold the extrusions very securely prior to installing the corner brackets.

The smaller tool is used to set the location of the front Z axis rod mount location precisely.

I will be creating a video to explain how to use these shortly....Stay tuned!

Another version I may try. Definitely looks to be an interesting extruder design. The other parts (lid, arm, and pin) should be the same from Kistenschieber. With all these versions and revisions I might just go ahead and order the aluminum extruder and make a custom mount for it too.

Update: I just reupped the body file, somehow the inlet funnel was lost off of the model while I was tinkering. Also countersunk one of the screws that would get in the way of the tension arm.

This is a combination of the Octopus Mug and the "Star Spawn of Cthulhu" figure. If your not sure why I used the name Cthulhu in the title of this mug, just look inside!  
Note: I added some rectangular supports under the tentacles on the lower half of the handle because I didn't thing they would print properly. Even with them that part of the handle is a little rough (on my printrbot simple). It is usable and looks ok, but could be improved if anyone has any ideas.

title: Bed leveling nut traps - MG Prusa Mendel

description.text: These traps remove the need for the nylock nuts under the laser cut Y carriage, and keep the leveling nuts from spinning.

1) Print 4 of these
2) Insert an M4 hex nut into the trap and slip it over the lobes on the Y carriage.
3) Screw bed into nut and through hole in the lobe.
4) Enjoy faster bed leveling and less bed vibration.

comments.text: did this work out for you well? one thing i noticed that by tightening too much, the laser cut bed actually bends and makes it harder for it to slide along the y-axis. i would imagine that throwing the bolt in this would cause it to bend faster sicne it would be pulling up on the bed

Simple Adapter plate for road shoes to be able to be used with Crank Brothers Egg Beaters, Adapter plate is setup for 2 hole pattern (I'm working on the 3, will post when done) simply bolt cleat to the top of adapter. the side risers contact the pedal so no spacer are needed on the pedal, while still low enough to walk decent. These shed mud easy so next time transition is muddy just laugh at the "Other Guy" as they are bent over clean mud out of their cleat racking up T1 times.

3 Hole Pattern requires 2 (Flange Locknuts M5 x 0.8 mm Thread) for cleat mount. They fit into adapter upside down. this is for flange to catch and the lowest profile possible.

description.text:
Originally produced by Games Workshop for their 6mm scale table top wargame, Epic. They have since abandoned all support for their game, so I modeled this in Autodesk Inventor for any avid wargamers.

Scaled to match the FW model, so it is considerably larger than the official GW models.

Epic is being re-released as Adeptus Titanicus some time in the near future, though reports indicate it will initially be titans only. Apparently it will be 8mm scale instead of 6mm, so I suggest that anyone wanting to print this for AT gaming should upscale it by 133%

Overall this took far more time than I expected, but I really like the result.

title: Quick Set Height for Makita Endmills - Shapeoko 3

description.text:
Some quick prints to help align the height of my 1/8" endmills for my Shapeoko 3's Makita router.

You just drop the endmill in to the one with the height you want, and then insert it into the collet. I wouldn't call it precise enough to set your Z height with, but it does do well enough for accurate amounts of stickout and is a much more convenient way of inserting the endmills. Don't try and tighten it down fully with this - use the wrenches like normal after using these to snug it up!

The files are the stickout height in inches, then the tool diameter in inches. So 0.7_125 is 0.7" stickout for a 0.125" (1/8") endmill.

author: john3d

description.text:
First off: NOT A WORKING GUN.
Second: CHECK YOUR LAWS!
This is a prop gun! There are no moving parts, and there is no way to use it as a weapon (shy of beating people. But don't do that. It's rude). There may also be laws in your area (federal, state, and local) that may apply to making, selling/giving, and using these. I have stuck a link at the bottom for this. With those two cleared, please PLEASE show some love to the original model by mikearnold! This took me mere moments to split compared to the time he plowed into the model! This was sliced using Netfab, and the STL files were repaired using Netfabs online cloud services. Each of the STL's are small enough to be printed on most RepRap's and even some of the smaller printers. The largest part is the hammer at 7cm x 7cm x 2cm. The parts can be glued with any glue that will work on ABS, or welded using acetone/ABS juice (which is how I did it). As a note: muzzle_2 has no "fixed" tag to it. Netfabb could not repair that STL, but it printed just fine as is.
And a second note: chamber2 has an odd hunk missing from it. It doesn't seem to show up in models/STL, but it ends up going missing during the print. Using ABS paste will fill this in lickty split. PSS: Thanks to Terminus for pointing this out: due to US laws, I would HIGHLY recommend you paint the barrel orange as to comply with the US Code 5001. Details on code 5001.
All though this is a federal law that you should adbid by, you should also check your local laws. If you need to, call your local police station, or the police station of the place you plan to show this off at to ensure you are not stepping on any legal toes.

1)Create Gcode that works for you
2)Print one of each part
3)Glue the parts using ABS juice (recommended) or an ABS safe glue. I would highly recommand gluing parts 1 and 2 together, then gluing those parts together (for example, butt_1 and butt_2, then glue that to the solid hammer that is made from hammer_1 and hammer_2). This may result in the muzzle being a tad off, but it will prove to have a much stronger bound this way!
4)Smooth and paint
